prompt.input: write a 1-2 funny lines about mango

sampled.completion:
1. 1. Why don't scientists trust mangoes? Because they might be up to no good-ango. 

2. My friend said, "I don't trust mangoes, they always look suspicious." To which I replied, "Well, they are the top mango-logists, aren't they?"
2. 1. Why did the mango go to the doctor? Because it wasn't peeling well!

2. My friends always make fun of me because I have a mango for a phone case.
3. 1. Why don't mangoes ever argue? Because they know who the real peach is!
2. I told my wife she looks like a mango, she said, 'Oh, you flatter me!', then I realized I misspoke—I should have said pumpkin.
4. 1) Mangoes are like the comedians of the fruit world - they always make you laugh with their goofy shapes and tangy personalities.

2) Mangoes are like a stand-up comedian, they make you laugh even when they're a little bit cheesy.

sampled: Yes. The first two texts appear to be diverse as they do not relate directly to each other and have no apparent connection. The third and fourth texts are also diverse as they do not share a common theme or relate to each other.

sampled.completion:

2. 1. Why don’t scientists trust pineapples? Because they tend to be a bit sneaky, often hiding their real intentions beneath layers of deliciousness!
2. When I heard the pineapple was going to be the new president, I was like "You're kidding! A tropical fruit in charge? Sounds like a smoothie-cracy to me!"
3. - I heard that pineapples are the fruit of happiness, but you don't see them smiling!

4. 1. Pineapple isn’t just a tropical fruit, it’s also a great excuse to wear a Hawaiian shirt to a barbecue.
2. Who needs pineapple on pizza, when you can have bacon instead? Just kidding, pineapple is amazing on pizza too.

sampled: 1. The first two texts are about the negative opinion of the author about pineapple. The second two texts have no direct relation with the others. So, the first two are diverse but the second two are not. Therefore, the answer is "No" for the entire set.
